title: 106_s653
content: The "Safer Workplaces Act" and the "Safety and Health Whistleblower Protection Act" aim to protect employees from reprisals by allowing them to report any injury, illness, or unsafe condition without fear of discrimination. SEC. 103. PROHIBITION OF DISCRIMINATION. Amends the Occupational Safety and Health Act to prohibit discrimination against employees who refuse duties due to safety concerns. Requires communication of perceived danger to the employer. SEC. 104. PROCEDURE. Section 11(c) of the Occupational Safety and Health Act of 1970 is amended to allow employees to file a complaint within 180 days if they believe they have been discriminated against. The Secretary will conduct an investigation within 90 days of receiving the complaint to determine its merit. After investigating a complaint under Section 11(c) of the Occupational Safety and Health Act of 1970, the Secretary will notify both the complainant and the alleged violator of the findings. If a violation is found, a preliminary order for relief will be issued. The person accused or the complainant can file objections within 30 days and request a hearing. Failure to request a hearing promptly will not delay the preliminary order. If the Secretary does not issue findings within 90 days, a hearing can be requested. The hearing will be conducted by an administrative law judge, and a final order must be issued within 120 days of the recommended decision. Legal burdens of proof under section 1221 of title 5, United States Code, will apply. If a violation is found in response to a complaint, the Secretary can order corrective actions, reinstatement with compensation, compensatory and exemplary damages. The Secretary may also assess a sum against the violator. The Secretary can order corrective actions, reinstatement with compensation, compensatory and exemplary damages, and may assess a sum against the violator. Any person affected by a final order can seek review before the United States court of appeals within 60 days. The Secretary's order must be reviewed within 60 days according to chapter 7 of title 5, US Code. Orders subject to review cannot be challenged in criminal or civil proceedings. Failure to comply may result in a civil action filed in the district court for enforcement. The court can grant additional relief as necessary. The court has jurisdiction to grant additional relief in cases of noncompliance. SEC. 105 amends Section 17(j) of the Occupational Safety and Health Act to include the history of violations under section 11(c). SEC. 106 states that the amendments will take effect 90 days after the enactment of the Act. TITLE II includes amendments regarding the coverage of federal, state, and political subdivision employees under the Act. Section 17 of the Occupational Safety and Health Act of 1970 is amended to increase fines and penalties for violations. This includes extending the time period for fines and inserting new provisions for convictions. Section 17 of the Occupational Safety and Health Act of 1970 is amended to increase fines and penalties for violations. The amendments include changing the fines for violations in subsections (f) and (g) to align with section 3571 of title 18, United States Code.
